tag_text: WHAT TOPICS WOULD YOU LIKE TO EXPLORE
title: #InTheirWords
project_head:
WOMEN IN AMERICA CAN VOTE AND RUN FOR OFFICE. THEY ARE CEOS AND MOTHERS. THEY ARE SCIENTISTS, JOURNALISTS AND ATHLETES. BUT THERE ARE STILL CHALLENGES FACING WOMEN SUCH AS PAY EQUITY, PAID FAMILY LEAVE AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY.

HEAR FROM WOMEN WORKING AND LIVING IN AMERICA TODAY

#INTHEIRWORDS
credits_intro: Gender equality in the USA is still a work in progress. USA TODAY decided to step aside and let women tell their stories  #InTheirWords about everything from feminism, to motherhood, to glass ceilings. This project explores the issues women care about in America today and is a space for original voices to be heard.
share_intro: YOUR TURN. CONTINUE THIS CONVERSATION BY SHARING THIS VIDEO.

videos.videodescription: Carrie Hammer talks about beauty and confidence.
videos.sharelanguage: "Beauty really is a woman who is feeling amazing." @carriehammer
videos.questionasked: What do you think a beautiful woman looks like?
videos.intro: Meet Carrie Hammer. She's a clothing designer who specializes in career clothes for women.
videos.video_quotes: "Beauty really is a woman who is feeling amazing."

videos.videodescription: Carrie Hammer says the definition of feminism is equal rights for men and women.
videos.sharelanguage: "I know very few people who can't get on board with that message." @carriehammer
videos.questionasked: What do you think of the word feminism?
videos.intro: Meet Carrie Hammer. She's a clothing designer who specializes in career clothes for women.
videos.video_quotes: "I know very few people who can't get on board with that message."

videos.videodescription: Carrie Hammer  talks about how women can help one another in their careers.
videos.sharelanguage: "Now I like to think of it as, you know, the girls' clubs." @carriehammer
videos.questionasked: How can women help other women?
videos.intro: Meet Carrie Hammer. She's a clothing designer who specializes in career clothes for women.
videos.video_quotes: "Now I like to think of it as, you know, the girls' clubs."

videos.videodescription: The Rev. Mihee Kim-Kort talks about the tension between white progressive liberal feminism and feminism rooted in the experiences of women of color.
videos.sharelanguage: “Feminism is for everybody.” @miheekimkort
videos.questionasked: What do you think of the word feminism?
videos.intro: Meet Rev. Mihee Kim-Kort. She's an ordained Presbyterian minister and author.
videos.video_quotes: “Feminism is for everybody.”

videos.videodescription: The Rev. Mihee Kim-Kort talks about seiminary school and the expectation that female students conform as the stereotypical religious leader: a white man.
videos.sharelanguage: “They expected…women to sound like men…" @miheekimkort
videos.questionasked: Was there a time when you felt aware of your gender?
videos.intro: Meet Rev. Mihee Kim-Kort. She's an ordained Presbyterian minister and author.
videos.video_quotes: “They expected …women to sound like men."

videos.videodescription: The Rev. Mihee Kim-Kort talks about the challenges of juggling her family life with her career.
videos.sharelanguage: "How do we balance caring for our families, our careers...” @miheekimkort
videos.questionasked: What challenges do women face today?
videos.intro: Meet Rev. Mihee Kim-Kort. She's an ordained Presbyterian minister and author.
videos.video_quotes: "How do we balance caring for our families, our careers?”

videos.videodescription: Ashley Graham talks about her modeling career and how she has turned the negative connotation of a “plus size” model into an opportunity to prove that curves are in.
videos.sharelanguage: “Some like to call me a plus size model, some a fat model…” @theashleygraham
videos.questionasked: Tell us about your career.
videos.intro: Meet Ashley Graham. She's a model and body activist.
videos.video_quotes: “Some like to call me a plus-size model, some a fat model.”

videos.videodescription: Ashley Graham talks about speaking to groups of young women about body image and embracing their curves and bodies.
videos.sharelanguage: “It’s really hard to teach confidence…” @theashleygraham
videos.questionasked: You speak at high schools to teenage girls about body image. What advice do you give them?
videos.intro: Meet Ashley Graham. She's a model and body activist.
videos.video_quotes: “It’s really hard to teach confidence.”

videos.videodescription: Ashley Graham says feminism isn't just for women but equality for all people.
videos.sharelanguage: "We are standing up for rights, for equality..." @theashleygraham
videos.questionasked: What does feminism mean to you?
videos.intro: Meet Ashley Graham. She's a model and body activist.
videos.video_quotes: "We are standing up for rights, for equality."

videos.videodescription: Ann Friedman says gender bias is more subtle in the workplace today. She says women often wonder whether they are underqualified or "crazy," when in reality they may be experiencing setbacks in their career because they are women.
videos.tags: gender bias, gender differences, the glass ceiling, equality
videos.sharelanguage: "Is it because I’m a woman or I’m just not good enough?" @annfriedman
videos.questionasked: Can you tell me about a time your gender affected your career or pursuing your dreams?
videos.intro: Meet Ann Friedman. She's a magazine journalist.
videos.video_quotes: "Is it because I’m a woman or I’m just not good enough?"

videos.videodescription: Ann Friedman talks about being a feminist. She says it’s a way of looking at the world and differs for everyone.
videos.sharelanguage: “It’s trying to actively remedy some of those power imbalances." @annfriedman
videos.questionasked: What do you think of the word feminism?
videos.intro: Meet Ann Friedman. She's a magazine journalist.
videos.video_quotes: “It’s trying to actively remedy some of those power imbalances."

videos.videodescription: Ann Friedman says a big step for gender equality is paid family medical leave for all workers.
videos.tags: gender equality, Paid family leave, equality
videos.sharelanguage: “It’s also an issue that effects other people in the workplace who don’t have kids.” @annfriedman
videos.questionasked: What issues affect gender equality in the workplace?
videos.intro: Meet Ann Friedmannn. She's a magazine journalist.
videos.video_quotes: “It’s also an issue that affects other people in the workplace who don’t have kids.”

videos.videodescription: Emily May talks about progress she has seen for women in the workplace.
videos.sharelanguage: “During my lifetime I’ve seem so much progress.” @iHollaback
videos.questionasked: Have you seen progress for women in your lifetime?
videos.intro: Meet Emily May. She co-founded Hollaback!, a movement to end street harrassment.
videos.video_quotes: “During my lifetime, I’ve seen so much progress.”

videos.videodescription: Emily May says feminism isn't just about men and women but the right of all people to feel comfortable in the world.
videos.sharelanguage: “Feminism...is about the right to be you.”@iHollaback
videos.questionasked: What do you think of the word feminism?
videos.intro: Meet Emily May. She co-founded Hollaback!, a movement to end street harrassment.
videos.video_quotes: “Feminism ... is about the right to be you.”

videos.videodescription: Renee Dixon talks about the pressures for men and women to provide for their family and have time at home.
videos.sharelanguage: "You wonder if going back to work would help your family.” - Renee Dixon
videos.questionasked: From your own experience or from hearing from friends, do you think there’s pressure for moms to stay home with their kids or pressure to work outside the home?
videos.intro: Meet Renee Dixon. She's a mother of three who homeschools her kids and works as a realtor.
videos.video_quotes: "You wonder if going back to work would help your family.”

videos.videodescription: Renee Dixon tells her daughters that being a woman comes with a lot of responsibility.
videos.sharelanguage: “We have intuitions and instincts, that are exclusive to us.” - Renee Dixon
videos.questionasked: What advice do you give your daughters?
videos.intro: Meet Renee Dixon. She's a mother of three who homeschools her kids and works as a realtor.
videos.video_quotes: “We have intuitions and instincts that are exclusive to us.”

videos.videodescription: Renee Dixon says equality is one of the biggest issues facing women.
videos.sharelanguage: “We need to be equal, but not expected to be the same.” - Renee Dixon
videos.questionasked: Do you think there are certain issues women are concerned about?
videos.intro: Meet Renee Dixon. She's a mother of three who homeschools her kids and works as a realtor.
videos.video_quotes: “We need to be equal, but not expected to be the same.”

videos.videodescription: Natalia Oberti Noguera talks about highlighting the diversity that already exists in addition to creating more diversity in the tech industry.
videos.sharelanguage: "While the numbers are low they're not zero." @nakisnakis
videos.questionasked: How can we increase diversity in tech fields?
videos.intro: Meet Natalia Oberti Noguera, the founder of Pipeline Fellowship. Pipeline gets women involved in angel investing and creates capital for female-led startups.
videos.video_quotes: "While the numbers are low, they're not zero."

videos.videodescription: Natalia Oberti Noguera talks about the joys of being her own boss.
videos.sharelanguage: "I'm my own boss, I have my own agency..." @nakisnakis
videos.questionasked: What advice do you give to women starting their own business?
videos.intro: Meet Natalia Oberti Noguera, the founder of Pipeline Fellowship. Pipeline gets women involved in angel investing and creates capital for female-led startups.
videos.video_quotes: "I'm my own boss, I have my own agency."

videos.videodescription: Jocelyn Frye says feminism is about women taking control of their destiny.
videos.sharelanguage: "You should feel empowered to make the choice that makes sense for you..." - Jocelyn Frye
videos.questionasked: What do you think of the word feminism?
videos.intro: Meet Jocelyn Frye. She's a lawyer and an expert on pay equity.
videos.video_quotes: "You should feel empowered to make the choice that makes sense for you."

videos.videodescription: Jocelyn Frye talks about the pay gap between men and women in the workplace.
videos.sharelanguage: "We want people to be paid fairly." - Jocelyn Frye
videos.questionasked: What is the gender pay gap?
videos.intro: Meet Jocelyn Frye. She's a lawyer and an expert on pay equity.
videos.video_quotes: "We want people to be paid fairly."

videos.videodescription: Jocelyn Frye tells young women to be confident and bold.
videos.sharelanguage: "We all come to the table with different, individual talents." - Jocelyn Frye
videos.questionasked: What advice would you give to younger women?
videos.intro: Meet Jocelyn Frye. She's a lawyer and an expert on pay equity.
videos.video_quotes: "We all come to the table with different, individual talents."

videos.videodescription: When Jocelyn Frye was a young girl, people told her she couldn't be a lawyer because of her race and gender.
videos.sharelanguage: "I'm sort of surprised by the fact that it didn't affect me." - Jocelyn Frye
videos.questionasked: Was there a time when your gender felt like an obstacle?
videos.intro: Meet Jocelyn Frye. She's a lawyer and an expert on pay equity.
videos.video_quotes: "I'm sort of surprised by the fact that it didn't affect me."

videos.videodescription: Jocelyn Frye says we should respect the different choices women make for themselves.
videos.sharelanguage: "There's so many judgments that are often leveled against women." - Jocelyn Frye
videos.questionasked: How can women help other women?
videos.intro: Meet Jocelyn Frye. She's a lawyer and an expert on pay equity.
videos.video_quotes: "There's so many judgments that are often leveled against women."

videos.videodescription: Sylvia Earle talks about the attitude toward women in science when she started her career. She says she applied to lead the first team of female aquanauts in 1970 because it didn’t say on the application that women should not apply. So she did.
videos.sharelanguage: “It was not considered the appropriate thing for women to do…” @SylviaEarle
videos.questionasked: When you began in the science field, what were some of the main barriers that women faced?
videos.intro: Meet Dr. Sylvia Earle, an oceanographer with over 50 years of experience, author, and a  National Geographic Explorer-in-Residence.
videos.video_quotes: “It was not considered the appropriate thing for women to do.”

videos.videodescription: Sylvia Earle says that women still face hardships in obtaining leadership roles in the workplace. She says female leaders provide a more collaborative approach to leadership.
videos.tags: STEM fields, the glass ceiling, equal opportunity,  leadership
videos.sharelanguage: “Today in positions of leadership women continue to be in the minority.”  @SylviaEarle
videos.questionasked: Have you seen progress for women in your lifetime?
videos.intro: Meet Dr. Sylvia Earle, an oceanographer with over 50 years of experience, author, and a  National Geographic Explorer-in-Residence.
videos.video_quotes: “Today in positions of leadership, women continue to be in the minority.”

videos.videodescription: Sylvia Earle talks about the struggle of balancing her career with child care. She says she was lucky to have had parents who helped her, but she feels as if she missed out on a lot of things.
videos.sharelanguage: "Those moments are gone...I can't recapture." @SylviaEarle
videos.questionasked: Tell us about a time your gender affected your life choices.
videos.intro: Meet Dr. Sylvia Earle, an oceanographer with over 50 years of experience, author, and a  National Geographic Explorer-in-Residence.
videos.video_quotes: "Those moments are gone ... I can't recapture."

videos.videodescription: Angela Hucles says we need to educate young people and their mentors about the benefits sports provide.
videos.sharelanguage: "I've benefited personally not just from a physical standpoint." @WomensSportsFdn
videos.questionasked: How can we get more girls to play sports?
videos.intro: Meet Angela Hucles. She's a two-time Olympic gold medalist for US Soccer.
videos.video_quotes: "I've benefited personally not just from a physical standpoint."

videos.videodescription: Angela Hucles says parents and mentors can help girls develop a healthy body image.
videos.sharelanguage: "Having a healthy body image comes in a variety of shapes and sizes." @WomensSportsFdn
videos.questionasked: How can we help young girls develop a healthy body image?
videos.intro: Meet Angela Hucles. She's a two-time Olympic gold medalist for US Soccer.
videos.video_quotes: "Having a healthy body image comes in a variety of shapes and sizes."

videos.videodescription: Angela Hucles talks about not having a girls team to play soccer with when she was growing up.
videos.sharelanguage: "From a very early age I was aware of my differences." @WomensSportsFdn
videos.questionasked: Tell us about a time your gender affected your career.
videos.intro: Meet Angela Hucles. She's a two-time Olympic gold medalist for US Soccer.
videos.video_quotes: "From a very early age, I was aware of my differences."

videos.videodescription: Angela Hucles says there's been tremendous progress since Title IX was passed.
videos.sharelanguage: "Two in five girls are participating in high school sports." @WomensSportsFdn
videos.questionasked: Has there been progress for women in sports?
videos.intro: Meet Angela Hucles. She's a two-time Olympic gold medalist for US Soccer.
videos.video_quotes: "Two in five girls are participating in high school sports."

videos.videodescription: Sabrina Hersi Issa talks about how progress is linked to privilege. She says the real question is who gets to be the recipient of privilege or the victim of circumstance.
videos.sharelanguage: “Progress is a product of privilege.” @beingbrina
videos.questionasked: Do you feel progress has been made for women in your lifetime in your field?
videos.intro: Meet Sabrina Hersi Iss. Issa. She founded Be Bold Media.
videos.video_quotes: “Progress is a product of privilege.”

videos.videodescription: Sabrina Hersi Iss says the next step for women moving forward is having a conversation about the impact of economic subjugation of women, people of color and marginalized groups and real solutions about how to address those issues.
videos.tags: progress, women of color, economic freedom
videos.sharelanguage: “Usually the conversation is framed as women are the victims...” @beingbrina
videos.questionasked: What progress would you like to see for women moving forward?
videos.intro: Meet Sabrina Hersi Iss. Issa. She founded Be Bold Media.
videos.video_quotes: “Usually the conversation is framed as women are the victims.”

videos.videodescription: Sabrina Hersi Iss says that women in America face the challenge of being seen as worthy. She says there is a class of worthiness in America where some women are worthy depending on their race or religion.
videos.sharelanguage:
“The struggle I’ve seen for Muslim women is having their full humanity respected…."
 @beingbrina
videos.questionasked: As a Muslim American do you feel that there are unique challenges that face Muslim women in America?
videos.intro: Meet Sabrina Hersi Iss. Issa. She founded Be Bold Media.
videos.video_quotes: “The struggle I’ve seen for Muslim women is having their full humanity respected."

people.person_bio: Ann Friedman, 33, is a magazine journalist and the former executive editor of GOOD magazine. Friedman writes about the Internet, politics, culture and gender. She also co-hosts the podcast "Call your Girlfriend" with Aminatou Sow.
people.person_intro: Meet Ann Friedman. She's a magazine journalist.

people.person_bio: Ashley Graham, 27, is known for her work as a lingerie model for the plus-size clothing retailer Lane Bryant. She has been featured in magazines like Vogue, Sports Illustrated and Glamour. Graham considers herself to be a body activist and encourages women to embrace their curves.
people.person_intro: Meet Ashley Graham. She's a model and body activist.

people.person_bio: Jocelyn Frye, 51, is senior fellow at the Center for American Progress and an expert on pay equity and women's issues. She served in the White House as a deputy assistant to President Obama and a director of policy for Michelle Obama with a special focus on women and children.
people.person_intro: Meet Jocelyn Frey. She's an expert on pay equity and directed policy on women's issues for Michelle Obama.

people.person_bio: Emily May, 33, co-founded Hollaback!, an organization that works to end street harrassment and empower women who are catcalled on the street. The group's website and mobile app give women and men an outlet to share experiences and find support.
people.person_intro: Meet Emily May. She founded Hollaback!, a movement to end street harrassment.

people.person_bio: Angela Hucles is a two-time Olympic gold medalist for US Soccer and a two-time World Cup bronze medalist. She also played professional soccer player for the Boston Breakers. Hucles is now president of the Women's Sports Foundation and advocates getting young women involved in sports.
people.person_intro: Meet Angela Hucles. She's a two-time Olympic gold medalist for US Soccer.

people.person_bio: Carrie Hammer, 29, is a clothing designer specializing in career clothes for women. She started her self-titled clothing line after being disappointed in the professional clothes available to women. She hosts an annual show at New York Fashion Week called 'Role models not runway models' that celebrates women who are at the top of their field professionally.
people.person_intro: Meet Carrie Hammer. She's a clothing designer who specializes in career clothes for women.

people.person_bio: Natalia Oberti Noguera, 31, is the founder and CEO of Pipeline Fellowship. Pipeline gets women involved in angel investing and creates capital for female-led startups.
people.person_intro: Meet Natalia Oberti Noguera. She founded Pipeline Fellowship, an organization that creates capital for female-led startups.

people.person_bio: Mihee Kim-Kort, 37, is an ordained Presbyterian minister. She's the author of several books including Making Paper Cranes: Toward an Asian American Feminist Theology and Yoked: Stories of a Clergy Couple in Marriage, Family, and Ministry, which she wrote with her husband Andrew Kort.
people.person_intro: Meet Rev. Mihee Kim-Kort. She's an author and ordained Presbyterian minister.

people.person_bio: Sabrina Hersi Issa, 31, founded Be Bold Media, a digial company that focuses on global advocacy and media innovation. She advocates for women in technology.
people.person_intro: Meet Sabrina Hersi Issa. She founded Be Bold Media.

people.person_bio: Meet Dr. Sylvia Earle, a National Geographic Explorer-in-Residence , author, lecturer and oceanographer with over 50 years of experience. Dr. Earle has logged more than 7,000 hours underwater and led the first team of women aquanauts during the Tektite Project in 1970.
people.person_intro: Meet Dr. Sylvia Earle, an oceanographer with over 50 years of experience, author, and a  National Geographic Explorer-in-Residence.

people.person_bio: Renee Dixon, 48, is a mother of three. She homeschools her children and works as a realtor.
people.person_intro: Meet Renee Dixon. She's a mother of three who homeschools her kids.
